descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on the psychological understanding of evil. Beginning from a definitional perspective on evil, the course moves to theories of evil. The core of the course is explanation of Philip Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment in its original form with a current critique by Zimbardo of his findings in the original experiment. From this basis the psychological dimensions of evil are developed, leading to a description of major explanations of the reality of evil. Special attention will be paid to an understanding of evil as this area relates to the lives of members of the class. Carries social science credit.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course the student will be expected to achieve the following objectives: (1) develop an understanding of evil both from an historical viewpoint and current views of evil (2) comprehend Zimbardo's Stanfored Prison experiment in its basic dimensions (3) critique the findings of the Zimbardo Stanford Prison experiment (4) evaluate Zimbardo's assessment of the Stanford Prison experiment (5) articulate a personal theory of evil as it relates to the student's life.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Course text will be The Lucifer Effect, by Philip Zimbardo, Random House, New York, ISBN # 978-1-4000-6411-3
